G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that any lessor who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be liable in tort for actual and statutory damages, including “three months’ rent or three times the damages sustained by [the tenant], whichever is greater,” together with the costs of the action and reasonable attorney’s fees.

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was the landlord and lessor of the Premises, and Plaintiff was a residential tenant entitled to the protections of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 93A and related Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was the landlord and lessor of the Premises, and Plaintiff was a residential tenant entitled to the protections of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 93A and related Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and applicable court rules because the Premises are located in Lowell, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: Conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., may evidence a breach of quiet enjoyment when they materially impair the character or value of the leased premises.

105 C.M.R. 410.010, 410.020, 410.500, 41.raw_text: 105 C.M.R. 410.010, 410.020, 410.500, 410.550, 410.602 (minimum standards; structural soundness; moisture and ventilation requirements)
105 C.M.R. 410.010, 410.020, 410.500, 41.proposition: Under the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, the landlord is responsible for maintaining the dwelling in compliance with minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, including keeping the dwelling free from chronic dampness and conditions conducive to mold growth.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The implied warranty of habitability, as recognized in Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199–201, and its statutory counterpart in G.L. c. 239, § 8A, further underscore that landlords must maintain premises in a condition fit for human habitation and in compliance with the State Sanitary Code; violation of these standards supports and informs the inference of an interference with quiet enjoyment.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from “serious interference with their tenancy—acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises.”
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but in this excerpt it focuses on the landlord’s fault requirement (at least negligence) and the relationship between the lead paint statute and § 14. It does not articulate or quote a general definition that the covenant protects against “serious interference with tenancy—acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises.” That specific formulation appears in other Massachusetts cases, not in this segment of Al‑Ziab.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from “serious interference with their tenancy—acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises.”
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly defines “quiet enjoyment” in the common-law landlord-tenant context using nearly the exact language of the proposition. It states that the phrase signifies the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences with the tenancy—acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises—and relies on prior Massachusetts cases for that formulation. Thus, the case directly supports the quoted proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]).”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–89 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy significant defects or conditions that affect health or safety, after notice, can constitute an “indirect interference” with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to cover a landlord’s omissions, including failure to repair known serious defects, and holds that Cruz Management’s failure to correct numerous sanitary, building, and fire code violations (inadequate heat and hot water, vermin infestation, etc.), after notice, violated § 14. The opinion emphasizes that a landlord’s acts or omissions that substantially impair the value of the leased premises constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment, and specifically cites prior cases where failure to repair defects after notice violated § 14. This fits the proposition that such non-repair can be an “indirect interference” with quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case… A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. See Simon v. Solomon… Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.… Dorgan v. Loukas…. Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy significant defects or conditions that affect health or safety, after notice, can constitute an “indirect interference” with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to cover not only direct acts but also a landlord’s omissions that permit a harmful condition to persist, and explicitly ties liability to what the landlord “failed to do or permitted to be done.” It holds that if the landlord, after notice of serious criminal activity by nontenants in common areas, takes no or inadequate measures to remove them and that condition seriously interferes with tenants’ use of the premises, this can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment. That fits the concept of an “indirect interference” through failure to remedy dangerous conditions after notice.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., may evidence a breach of quiet enjoyment when they materially impair the character or value of the leased premises.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurring/dissenting opinion focused on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent obligations, not on covenant of quiet enjoyment. The justice discusses Code violations as evidence of breach of an implied statutory/codified standard, and expressly distinguishes this from broader, undefined obligations, but nowhere links Code violations to a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, this text does not support the proposition that Sanitary Code violations may evidence a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: If it were now necessary or appropriate to indicate by dictum what the ultimate scope of our new rule might be, beyond the necessities of the present cases, I would state it to be (a) that by renting a dwelling unit a landlord impliedly agrees, with respect to the minimum standards prescribed by any applicable laws, regulations or codes (such as the State Sanitary Code) having the force and effect of law, (i) that the rented unit complies with such standards at the time of the renting, and (ii) that he will do whatever such laws, regulations or codes require a landlord to do for compliance with such standards during the term of the renting.

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and statutory damages, as well as costs and reasonable attorney’s fees as provided by G.L. c. 186, § 14, even though she presently appears pro se.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 as authorizing actual or statutory damages plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees, and it affirms that such fees are recoverable even when counsel is a legal services organization. It does not address, however, whether a plaintiff who is presently appearing pro se—but who has no attorney—may recover attorney’s fees; in fact, the case involves representation by law students and a supervising attorney and an award of fees to that program. Thus it cannot be cited as authority that a current pro se litigant is entitled to attorney’s fees under § 14.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The payment of attorney’s fees is authorized explicitly by G. L. c. 186, § 14. An unsuccessful defendant is liable for ‘the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ No exception is made where counsel is a legal services organization nor where the defendant is a public entity such as the BHA. We said recently that ‘when attorney’s fees are statutorily authorized legal service organizations are entitled to receive such awards.’”
